entry.title: Calibration end date vs Form end date
entry.content:
Hello,

We have found out a conflict between end dates in Calibration and Performance Management.

- Calibration end date = date 00h00min e.g. 31st Dec 2025 00h00m

- Form end date = date 23h59 min e.g. 31 st Dec 2025 23h59

You can see detailed end date in Integration Center > Starting Entity: TrendData_SysOverallPerformance.

Example:

userIdidStart DateEnd DatePerformance RatingLast ModifiedModuleRatingSource
1000068811320901/01/2025 01:0001/01/2026 00:59EXCEEDS EXPECTATIONS07/07/2025 16:13Performance Manager3Form
1000068811698901/01/2025 01:0031/12/2025 01:00NOT MEETING EXPECTATIONS24/07/2025 19:21Calibration1Calibration

This causes issues in People Profile because the sorting order is based on the rating end date : 2635378 - Sorting Order of Background and Trend Data in Employee Profile - SAP for Me

So the common belief that PM form dates and Calibration dates should match is incorrect because of the design.

To have the correct order in People Profile you have to set the dates as follows:

- Form end date = 31 st Dec 2025 23h59

- Calibration end date = 1st Jan 2026 00h00

Could SAP SuccessFactors team advise on when they are going to make end dates and times match?

Kind Regards,

Abdelrani

P.S.: the time displayed is in UTC+1 because of my options even if the Platform setting is set to UTC.

entry.title: Re: Validation Rules
entry.content:
@sotirisgiog 

In SAC validation rules are more driven from Master Data and not fact Data. Generally its based on attributes or hard coded member values. 

You cannot define validation rules based on fact data but what you can do is re classify the input data into right combination using past historical fact records using a Data Action. 

Please note this will not prevent any wrong combination input but only re process the data into right combination post the Data Action run.

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Why do parked invoices (e.g doc. type, RE, DR) not di...
entry.content:
Dear @Eduard5,

Question 1.

In Public Cloud a parked supplier invoice (document type RE) is not treated like a parked FI journal entry. For RE, SAP parks the MM supplier-invoice document (Invoice Verification object) and does not create the FI expense/G/L line items yet. Because those FI G/L line items don‚Äôt exist, they also can‚Äôt be stored in / exposed by the FI parked-document structures (VBKPF/VBSEG*) and therefore don‚Äôt show up in Manage Journal Entries or in the released I_ParkedOplAcctgDoc* CDS views.

SAP explicitly describes this as standard behavior and contrasts it with parked G/L journal entries where a full parked FI document is created immediately so yes what you‚Äôre seeing is effectively a light accounting representation on the FI side for parked RE invoices until posting, there are no FI expense postings to report (no debit lines, no CO assignments) only the supplier-invoice document data exists on the logistics/AP invoice object side

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3685396

Question 2.

Is there any CDS view that exposes cost objects for parked RE invoices before posting? Not via FI parked-document CDS views because the FI G/L items do not exist yet BUT you can get the cost objects from the Supplier Invoice (MM) API / CDS layer, which is where the parked invoice coding is actually stored

Use the released supplier-invoice interface CDS views such as:

  • I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01
  • I_SuplrInvoiceItemGLAcctAPI01

Those are the right data sources for parked RE invoice cost assignment before posting

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3273168

https://api.sap.com/cdsviews/I_SUPLRINVOICEITEMGLACCTAPI01

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: How to write Table function in stranded way like SAP
entry.content:
How to Write CDS Table Functions the Standard SAP Way

In SAP S/4HANA, we cannot always express complex business logic using pure CDS syntax. To manage scenarios like long text processing, procedural calculations, or important joins, SAP uses CDS Table Functions implemented through AMDP.

While many developers create table functions on the fly, SAP sticks to a strict and consistent design pattern across its standard content. This approach ensures good performance, readability, upgrade safety, and transportability.

A useful way to grasp this standard is to look at how SAP builds transactional CDS views, especially those that use CDS Table Functions. By examining SAP-delivered objects like I_SalesOrderTP, we can clearly see the structure, naming conventions, annotations, and implementation method that SAP expects developers to follow.

This guide explains how SAP writes table functions, how they implement them using AMDP, and how they use them in CDS views. This will help you design your own extensions in the same way SAP does.

  1. Start with a Standard View: I_SALESORDERTP.
  • SAP provides many standard CDS views in S/4HANA.
  • To understand how SAP writes table functions, the easiest example is the view: I_SALESORDERTP
  • This is a Transactional Processing View, delivered by SAP.

   2. Locate the Table Function Used Inside the View.

  • Inside the view, you will notice SAP has used: with parameters (...).

  • This indicates that the view is consuming a CDS Table Function.

        3. You will find the CDS Table Function that SAP has written.

    4.  Open the AMDP Class to See SAP‚Äôs Logic.

  • Once you find the Table Function name, open the AMDP class: cl_sd_S4h_stxl_utils=>get_header_text
  • Inside this class, SAP has written the entire logic.

When crafting Table Functions ", in the manner SAP does " consistently adhere to this structure:

Create a CDS Table Function with parameters.

Implement it via an AMDP class/method using native SQLScript.

Consume it in your final CDS view using with parameters.

Follow the exact naming, annotation, and structure shown in standard objects such as I_SalesOrderTP, I_PurchaseOrderTP, I_BillingDocumentTP, etc.

Following this pattern guarantees:

Best performance (native HANA execution)

Transportability and upgrade-safety

Consistency with thousands of standard SAP-delivered objects

Conclusion

It is a tried-and-true architectural best practice to use SAP's standard pattern for CDS Table Functions. You can align your custom developments with the same design principles used in core SAP objects like *I_SalesOrderTP*, *I_PurchaseOrderTP*, and *I_BillingDocumentTP* by defining a CDS Table Function with parameters, implementing its logic in an AMDP method using native SQLScript, and consuming it through a final CDS view.


This method guarantees that sophisticated logic runs directly on SAP HANA for maximum efficiency, stays neatly isolated from the consumption layer, and is resilient to upgrades and transports. More significantly, because it adheres to a well-known and extensively used standard, it makes your solution instantly comprehensible to other SAP developers.

entry.title: Re: SOST - Subject translation issue
entry.content: Why would you expect the system to translate the subject that is derived from a long text (especially in the cast of long text) in SOST? SOST is only going to show the email record as it was created, which would be subject to whichever language was used when the email was created, and further it would not be aware of anything that is developed/configured in QM01.

entry.content:
@michael_smithe5 you can assign each SMBC object to a configuration group. You can then create a filter on configuration group level and save it as a variant. I don't know if you can then create a custom tile that launches the F4579 app with a predefined variant. 
Please also note that the visibility of each SMBC object in F4579 depends on the authorization. If you don't have permission, you won't be able to see it. This way, you can also ensure that different users can see different configuration objects even though they use the same app.

SAP Global Trade Services

entry.title: New Learning Journey LJv4 : Implementing SAP Customer Data Cloud
entry.content:
Announcing: Implementing SAP Customer Data Cloud Learning Journey

We are thrilled to announce the launch of our comprehensive learning journey, Implementing SAP Customer Data Cloud. This carefully designed program is crafted to equip you with the advanced skills and in-depth knowledge necessary to harness the full potential of SAP Customer Data Cloud.

Who this is for:
Target audience: Business users, Admin users, Consultants and Developers  who want to expand their functional knowledge and technical skills with SAP Customer Data Cloud.

What You Will Learn:

This learning journey will guide you through the main concepts and functionalities of SAP Customer Data Cloud. You will gain an in-depth understanding of the implementation of the key business scenarios of the SAP Customer Data Cloud solution. In addition, you will discover the B2B capabilities of SAP Customer Data Cloud. It consists of two courses, a hands-on practice system, and instructor-led training.

Certification Opportunity: Upon completion of this learning journey, you will be well-prepared to earn a valuable certification, validating your skills and knowledge in SAP Customer Data Cloud.

Join us and unlock the full potential of SAP Customer Data Cloud. Enrol now and take the first step toward advanced customer data management and analytics.

How to access:
The learning journey is available now on learning.sap.com. The courses are FREE. The practice system requires an SAP Learning Hub license.

entry.title: Re: regarding Backorder Processing (BOP)
entry.content:
Hello @S-O

Thank you for the follow-up question.

The reason for that is, BOP runs background reallocation and no produces schedule-line update for credit-blocked items, while the manual availability check in VA02 is a full ATP check and it also commits its result to the order even if the credit status is still blocked.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue in Printing 7 Copies of Invoice ‚Äì Item Table No...
entry.content:
Hello @nag_7589,

Thank you for your response.

Your approach works correctly in ECC and S/4HANA On-Premise, where we can set the ‚ÄúNumber of Copies‚Äù in the print parameters.

However, my requirement is for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and unfortunately the Public Cloud Output Management framework does not support printing multiple copies using print parameters.

In S/4HANA Cloud:

1.Only one print job can be triggered per billing document

2.The system does not provide a ‚Äúnumber of copies‚Äù option

Therefore, SAP recommends generating multiple copies inside the Adobe Form itself This is why I am using the repeat-occurrence approach to produce 7 invoice copies in one PDF.

My current challenge is:

1.Full invoice (header + items + totals) is not repeating inside the repeated layout

2.No copy number is provided from backend, so I must control labels using the repetition index inside the form

So the ECC method unfortunately cannot be applied in S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Thank you for your input.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany Investment WBS Settlement Option in SAP...
entry.content:
Good day @Tirukanagouda_K 

Thank you for your question.

The simple answer is, no. However, I will explain the reason below.

To summarise, the public cloud does not support cross company settlement when Asset Accounting is involved. Investment WBS, AuC and final asset must be attached to the same company code. This is also confirmed in KBA 3456675. You can find the detail here: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3456675

That means, there is no standard option to perform an intercompany settlement between investment WBS elements before or instead of asset transfer.

My recommendation is to:

  • Settle the investment project in company code A to AuC and final asset.
  • Use Intercompany Asset Transfer within same country (1IH) to move the asset between your company codes. Below you will find more details on Scope Item 1IH

https://help.sap.com/docs/help/979ee481d97045cb8857e3fac1d0073f/84f72ee1fda946dd8667c4a33171ff52.html?locale=en-US

Should you at anytime need earlier intercompany allocation, your usual design separate investment projects in each company code and use intercompany billing or internal charging, while you keep settlement itself strictly intra company.

This Blog provides some very useful insights: Settlement of Investment Projects in SAP Cloud ERP

You may also refer to this on how to run Settlment for Actual: 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/65511a912abd45518fdab7d995304e47.html?locale=en-US

Let me know if you have more questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Semantic search in CAP (Node.js): vector embeddings and cosine similarity
entry.content:
In this blog post I report on my recent experiments and findings on how to implement a semantic search in CAP Node.js. The goal for the search mechanism was to be able to find the item in an entity with the best semantic match based on a user query (prompt). This can be achieved using (local) vector embeddings and a cosine similarity search. I was pleasantly surprised how easy it is to handle vector embeddings locally without the need for an actual (vector) database (at least when not considering scaling).

While watching the Devtoberfest 2025 session on Agentic Coding with CAP by David Kunz, I was intrigued to inspect the source code of the CAP mcp-server that was talked about. Turns out, the search_docs tool of the server is implemented using vector embeddings and a cosine similarity search. This sparked my interest to explore this topic further and see how the concept can be applied to other scenarios as well.

To start off, I will give you my understanding of vector embeddings (which might not be scientifically accurate, but is sufficient for applying the concept): Vector embeddings are numerical representations of data. Each vector has a lot of dimensions and a numerical value for each of the dimensions. The number of dimensions depends on the embedding model used. Data that has similar meaning, let's say "banana" and "apple", will also be closer to each other in the dimensional space than "banana" and "computer". It is important to note that you can only compare vectors that were created using the same embedding model, as a comparison requires the same number of dimensions with the same meaning. To create vector embeddings in a (CAP) Node.js application, this is all we need:

import { pipeline } from "@xenova/transformers"
const embedder = await pipeline("feature-extraction", "Xenova/all-MiniLM-L6-v2")

const data = [
    {
        text: "banana"
    },
    {
        text: "apple"
    }
]

const createEmbeddings = async () => {
    for (const item of data) {
        const embedding = await embedder(item.text, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
        item.embedding = JSON.stringify(Array.from(embedding.data))
    }
    return data
}

console.log(await createEmbeddings()) // [{ text: 'banana', embedding: '[-0.057455405592918396,0.03617725893855095 ...

Going back to the original quest of implementing a semantic search, the next step is to compare the vector embedding of a user query with the vector embeddings of the existing items. For that, we use a cosine similarity search. The cosine similarity is a measure that calculates the cosine of the angle between two vectors in a multi-dimensional space. The result is a value between -1 and 1, where 1 means the vectors are identical, 0 means there is no similarity, and -1 means they are completely opposite. The principle here is that vectors that have a smaller angle between them (are closer to each other) are more similar in meaning. This concept is fundamental to how large-language models work. To calculate the cosine similarity between two vectors, we can use the following code:

// see code sample above for creating embeddings

import cosineSimilarity from "cosine-similarity"

const search = "computer"
const searchEmbedding = await embedder(search, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
const results = data.map(item => ({
    text: item.text,
    similarity: cosineSimilarity(Array.from(searchEmbedding.data), JSON.parse(item.embedding)).toFixed(4)
}))
console.log(results) // [ { text: 'banana', similarity: '0.4076' }, { text: 'apple', similarity: '0.5369' } ]

The cosine-similarity module essentially does all the heavy lifting for us. After creating the embedding for the search ("computer"), we compare it with each of the existing embeddings to get a similarity score. The higher the score, the similar the data is in meaning. As we can the in the logged result, "computer" is more similar to "apple" (0.5369) than to "banana" (0.4076) - for obvious reasons.

The next step is to integrate this search mechanism into a CAP application. I create a simple CAP service with a Products entity, that also exposed a semanticSearch function. In the handler for that function, we create the same logic as shown in the code sample above. The only difference is that we now fetch the existing items from the database (embeddings stored a string) and return the items sorted by their similarity to the search term. It is important to note that we create the embeddings not in the actual search handler, but during the initialization of the service - for obvious performance reasons.

import { pipeline } from "@xenova/transformers"
import cosineSimilarity from "cosine-similarity"

export default async function catalog() {
    const products = this.entities["Products"]
    const data = await SELECT.from(products)
    const embedder = await pipeline("feature-extraction", "Xenova/all-MiniLM-L6-v2")
    for (const item of data) {
        const embedding = await embedder(item.text, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
        await UPDATE(products, item.ID).with({ embedding: embedding.data })
    }

    this.on("semanticSearch", async (req) => {
        const { search } = req.data
        const data = await SELECT.from(products)
        let results
        const searchEmbedding = await embedder(search, { pooling: "mean", normalize: true })
        results = data.map(item => ({
            ...item,
            similarity: cosineSimilarity(Array.from(searchEmbedding.data), JSON.parse(item.embedding))
        }))
        results.sort((a, b) => b.similarity - a.similarity)
        for (const result of results) {
            delete result.embedding
        }
        return results
    })
}

Please note that this sample won't scale for large datasets, as we are loading all items into memory for the search. Also, we are storing the embeddings in the database as strings, which is not ideal. For larger datasets, a vector database like SAP HANA Cloud would be more appropriate. However, for smaller applications or testing/learning purposes, this approach should work fine.

We can now test this semantic search by calling http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/semanticSearch(search='computer'), which returns the following data:

{
    "@odata.context": "$metadata#Products",
        "value": [
            {
                "ID": 1,
                "text": "apple",
                "similarity": 0.5369198543970098
            },
            {
                "ID": 2,
                "text": "banana",
                "similarity": 0.40761179144643095
            }
        ]
}

Now let's the if customers would find the banane if they searched for /semanticSearch(search='yellow fruit with curved shape'):

{
    "@odata.context": "$metadata#Products",
        "value": [
            {
                "ID": 2,
                "text": "banana",
                "similarity": 0.40374334839388043
            },
            {
                "ID": 1,
                "text": "apple",
                "similarity": 0.2445011304736103
            }
        ]
}

And that's how we can implement a true semantic search in a CAP Node.js application! I was pleasantly surprised how easy it is to create and handle vector embeddings locally without the need for an actual vector database (at least for smaller datasets). Also, we didn't need to rely on any external APIs to large-language models or the like, the embedding model runs completely locally.

I hope you like this and maybe learned something new - I certainly did.

entry.title: Collective Value Helps in RAP: V2 and V4 Implementation Guide - Part 2
entry.content:
In Part 1 of this series, we explored the fundamentals of Collective Value Helps in RAP, covering implementation patterns across OData V2 and V4 service bindings. The community response has been overwhelming, with particular interest in hierarchical implementations for complex business scenarios.

While CDS hierarchies are extensively documented in the SAP ecosystem and widely used for representing parent-child relationships across business objects, a critical implementation gap exists: there are virtually no practical examples of incorporating hierarchical display patterns within Collective Value Helps. Part 2 bridges this gap by demonstrating how to seamlessly integrate hierarchical search templates into the collective value help framework we built in Part 1.

Watch the demonstration video below to see hierarchical value helps in action, including how they work alongside existing flat list search templates, in a Collective Value Help:


System Requirements

**Hierarchical Value Help Dialogs require: **

**SAP S/4HANA Cloud**
--Minimum Release: 2311
--Protocol: OData V4 service binding

**SAP S/4HANA On-Premise/Private Edition: **
--Minimum Release : S/4HANA 2025 onwards
--Protocol: OData V4 service binding

**Important: ** OData V2 does not support hierarchical visualization out of the box via CDS Hierarchy due to protocol limitations. CDS hierarchical patterns require OData V4.

CDS Hierarchies: Foundation for Hierarchical Value Helps

CDS (Core Data Services) hierarchies are well-established patterns in the SAP landscape for representing parent-child relationships. SAP provides comprehensive documentation and numerous community resources for learning hierarchy fundamentals:

  • Hierarchy Definition | SAP Help Portal
  • Treeviews with Read-Only Capabilities | SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Community: CDS Hierarchy Articles

This article focuses specifically on utilizing CDS hierarchies within RAP-compliant value helps and demonstrating how to incorporate hierarchical search templates alongside the flat templates created in Part 1.

Key Use Case: Hierarchies are particularly powerful in domains like Asset Management, where technical objects form complex parent-child structures that users need to navigate when making selections.

Business Context: Asset Management-> Hierarchical Relationships

In Asset Management, technical objects naturally form hierarchical structures that reflect real-world installations and organizational relationships:

Functional Location Hierarchies:

  • Parent functional locations contain child functional locations
  • Example: TATM ‚Üí TATM-UT3 ‚Üí TATM-UT3-001
  • Represents physical plant structure and organizational grouping

Equipment Hierarchies:

  • Equipment can be installed under functional locations
  • Equipment can be installed under other equipment (sub-assemblies)
  • Example: Main equipment (11947458) contains sub-equipment (11947627)

Mixed Hierarchies:

  • Equipment installed at functional locations
  • Sub-equipment installed under main equipment
  • Creates complex parent-child navigation requirements

A sample Hierarchy in Asset Management:

Transaction: IH01 - Structure List

Why Hierarchical Value Helps Matter:

When users select technical objects in business processes (work orders, maintenance notifications, asset transfers), they need to:

  • Understand the installation hierarchy
  • Navigate parent-child relationships visually
  • Select objects while seeing their organizational context
  • Identify relationships between equipment and functional locations

Standard flat list value helps lose this critical hierarchical context, making object selection difficult and error-prone in complex asset structures.

Implementation: Building the Hierarchical VDM Model

Step 1: Interface View (I-View) with Parent Association

The foundation of any CDS hierarchy is a self-association that establishes the parent-child relationship.

I-View

Critical Elements:

  • Self-Association _ParentNode: Establishes the many-to-one parent relationship
  • Cardinality [0..1]: Each node has either zero (root) or one parent
  • Join Condition: Links child's SuperiorTechnicalObject to parent's TechnicalObject

This I-View serves as the data foundation, providing the parent-child relationship that the hierarchy view will consume.

Step 2: Hierarchy View Definition

The hierarchy view transforms the I-View's parent association into an actual hierarchical structure with defined traversal rules.

Hierarchy View

Critical Hierarchy Annotations:

  1. source ZAR_I_TechObjHierarchy: References the I-View containing the parent association
  2. child to parent association _ParentNode: Specifies which association defines the hierarchy
  3. start where SuperiorTechnicalObject is initial: Defines root nodes (no parent = top of hierarchy)
  4. siblings order by TechnicalObject: Sorts nodes at the same level
  5. multiple parents not allowed: Enforces strict tree structure (each node has max one parent)

This hierarchy view establishes the traversal logic and structural rules for displaying the parent-child relationships.

 

Step 3: Consumption (C-View) Definition 

The consumption view serves as the bridge between the CDS hierarchy and the collective value help framework. It exposes the hierarchy as a searchable value help provider while maintaining the hierarchical data structure.

C-View

Critical Annotations:

  1. @ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities
    #VALUE_HELP_PROVIDER: Enables this view to provide value help data
    #SEARCHABLE_ENTITY: Allows search functionality within the value help dialog
    These capabilities are essential for user interaction
  2. @odata.hierarchy.recursiveHierarchy: [{ entity.name: 'ZAR_I_TechObjHierarchyView' }]
    THE CRITICAL HIERARCHICAL LINK
    Note: The entity name should reference the Hierarchy View (from Step 2), not the I-View or C-View itself.
    Points to the CDS hierarchy view created in Step 2
    Instructs OData V4 service to use hierarchical structure
    Without this annotation, hierarchy won't display in value help
  3. association of many to one ... as _ParentNode
    Recreates the parent association in the consumption layer
    Must match the join conditions from the I-View
    Required for OData V4 hierarchy metadata generation
    Links both TechnicalObject AND TechObjIsEquipOrFuncnLoc (composite key)


Step 4: Including Hierarchical Template in Collective Value Help

Now we integrate the hierarchical search template into our existing collective value help framework from Part 1:

CVH V2 Metadata Extension

CVH V4 Metadata Extension

Service Definition

OData V2 Service Binding: The Limitation

Service Binding OData V2

This eliminates the possibility of incorporating hierarchical search templates via CDS hierarchy in V2 collective value helps. OData V2's protocol limitations prevent hierarchy visualization in value help dialogs


OData V4 Service Binding: The Solution Path

Service Binding OData V4

The V4 service binding successfully exposes the hierarchical template without errors.


The Problem - Flat List Display

Even with a properly defined hierarchy view exposed in V4, the initial preview reveals an unexpected result:

Flat List Display (as opposed to expected Hierarchical display)


The Problem:
Despite having a hierarchical CDS view, the value help displays data as a flat list without any parent-child visualization. Users see individual records but lose all hierarchical context.

Why This Happens:
Creating a CDS hierarchy view is necessary but not sufficient for hierarchical display in value helps. The RAP framework requires explicit UI presentation instructions to render hierarchy in the value help dialog.

The Missing Piece: The framework needs explicit instructions via presentation variant annotations to understand that this data should be rendered as a hierarchy tree, not a flat table. Without these annotations, OData V4 treats the hierarchy view as just another data source.

The Solution - Presentation Variant Annotations
To provision hierarchical display in value helps, we must add specific presentation variant annotations that declare hierarchical visualization intent.

Consumption View (C-View) Annotations

C-View (Presentation Variant Added)

A presentation variant annotation needs to be included here which will contain the InitialExpansionLevel for the hierarchy and  a property RecursiveHierarchyQualifier.

RecursiveHierarchyQualifier - This annotation contains a string with the name of the hierarchy view and make possible that the data is then shown on UI as tree table. The projection view should also have the annotation

InitialExpansionLevel - This annotation indicates up to which level a display hierarchy shall be initially expanded.

Collective Value Help Metadata Extension

CVH V4 Metadata Extension (Presentation Variant annotation added)

A presentationVariantQualifier annotation needs to be included here, which should've the same value as the Qualifier in the C-View, i.e., 'HIERARCHY', in this case. This annotation indicates how the value help result should be displayed.

The Result: Hierarchical Value Help in Action

Hierarchical value help display

Success! The hierarchical variant now displays:

  • Parent-child relationships visualized as tree structure
  • Expand/collapse controls for navigation
  • Indentation showing hierarchy levels
  • Seamless integration with flat templates from Part 1
  • Full hierarchy traversal in value help dialog

User Experience - End Users can now:

  • Switch between flat and hierarchical search templates
  • Navigate parent-child relationships visually
  • Expand/collapse hierarchy nodes and even the entire Tree View
  • Select objects while understanding their organizational context
  • See equipment installation hierarchies and functional location structures

Key Takeaways: When to Use Hierarchical Collective Value Helps

Use Hierarchical Patterns When:

  • Parent-Child Relationships Matter: Business objects naturally form hierarchies (org structures, location hierarchies etc)
  • Context Aids Selection: Users need to see relationships to make correct selections
  • Navigation is Important: Users need to browse up/down hierarchies during selection
  • OData V4 is Available: V2 protocol does not support hierarchy visualization

Implementation Checklist:

  • Define I-View with self-association (_ParentNode)
  • Create hierarchy view with traversal rules (start where, siblings order by)
  • Use OData V4 service binding (V2 not supported)
  • Add presentation variant in C-View
  • Reference presentation variant in CVH metadata extension
  • Test expand/collapse and hierarchy navigation

Key Implementation points:

  • Cardinality Enforcement: multiple parents not allowed ensures tree structure
  • Root Node Definition: start where clause correctly identifies top-level nodes
  • Presentation Variant annotation must be added in C-View and CVH metadata
  • Qualifier Consistency: Same qualifier in C-View and CVH metadata


Series Conclusion
This two-part series has explored the complete spectrum of collective value helps in RAP:
Part 1 established the foundation:

  1. Basic collective value help concepts and structure
  2. Implementation across OData V2 and V4 service bindings
  3. Service binding architectural differences
  4. Nested value help workarounds
  5. Multi-dimensional search capabilities

Part 2 extended to advanced patterns:

  1. Hierarchical CDS view construction
  2. VDM model for hierarchy-enabled value helps
  3. OData V2 protocol limitations
  4. Presentation variant configuration for hierarchy visualization
  5. Seamless integration of flat and hierarchical search templates

Together, these patterns enable user-centric, multi-criteria search capabilities that leverage RAP's full value help framework while maintaining clean architectural separation and reusability.

Key Architectural Insight:
Collective value helps in RAP provide a powerful, user-centric approach to value help management by enabling multi-criteria search through a single, reusable model. The addition of hierarchical display patterns extends this capability to complex business scenarios requiring parent-child navigation‚Äîdelivering a comprehensive search experience that adapts to diverse user needs.

Conclusion
Hierarchical collective value helps represent the convergence of RAP's value help framework with CDS hierarchy capabilities, enabling rich, context-aware search experiences for complex business objects. While implementation requires careful attention to presentation variant configuration and V4 protocol requirements, the result is a powerful pattern applicable across any SAP domain where parent-child relationships drive user decision-making.
Whether you're building asset management applications, organizational hierarchies, material master navigation, or any scenario requiring hierarchical context during selection, this pattern provides the foundation for delivering intuitive, efficient user experiences.
The combination of CDS hierarchies, collective value helps, and RAP's presentation variant framework creates a powerful combination for solving complex data selection challenges-no custom coding required, just optimal usage of key annotations.
Thank you for following this two-part series. I welcome your feedback, and experiences implementing collective value helps in your own RAP applications.

entry.title: Re: How to set trigger for Integration Suite for periodic...
entry.content:
Hi @taao19710316 ,

In SAP Integration Suite, the standard timer event does not support an arbitrary list of dates (like holidays) out-of-the-box. It is designed to run on a repetitive schedule, e.g., defined days of the week or month.

For your use case‚Äîtriggering an iFlow periodically while excluding national or company holidays‚Äîa two-step approach is recommended:

  1. Use the standard timer for the base schedule

    • Configure the timer to run on the relevant weekdays (e.g., Monday‚ÄìFriday).

    • This handles the majority of your scheduling needs (roughly 80%).

  2. Filter out holidays using externalized parameters and Groovy scripting

    • Maintain a configurable parameter (e.g., in the Integration Flow‚Äôs properties) containing all holiday dates. The dates can be comma-separated in a consistent format, such as US date format or your company standard.

    • Add a Groovy script at the start of the iFlow that checks the current run date against this holiday list.

    • If the date matches a holiday, the script can stop further execution; otherwise, processing continues as usual.

This approach allows the iFlow to run on all weekdays but only process data on valid business days, and it keeps the solution flexible. You can update the holiday list for the next year‚Äîor even several years ahead‚Äîwithout modifying the interface design

entry.title: Re: Restricting Company Code Access in Run Statutory Repo...
entry.content:
Good day @Prasit_Arpornrat 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4de200b26d5d42bbacae69c6bf6b9923/fb15635742dced74e10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

In summary, run Statutory Reports does not offer a standalone setting in the app to restrict company code. The system relies on your organisation units for example your company code, which are then merged into reporting entities, authorisation and team responsibility checks. See: Setting Up Your Statutory Reporting for some insights.

There are some reasons why the desired restrictions when running reports does not work in your case. Some of those are:

  • Yor report category does not use company code as an organisational unit, or
  • Maybe the users you intend to restrict still have broader access, which was given to them through other roles, or
  • The intended user is assigned to some reporting entities that group several company codes.

In reference to those potential causes, you can achieve the restriction by:

  1. Ensuring the company code is used as an organisation unit in your statutory reporting and it is correctly assigned to reporting entities.
  2. Check the intended User‚Äôs business roles and restrict company code as desired.
  3. I advice you use Manage Teams and Responsibilities so that each user is only responsible for reporting entities that match their company code.

Some users may still see more values in the company code but they will only get tasks and can only run reports for the company codes you have authorised.

This link guides you through the statutory report: https://cdnapisec.kaltura.com/html5/html5lib/v2.101/mwEmbedFrame.php/p/1921661/uiconf_id/37285991/entry_id/0_oswzfw8h?wid=_1921661&iframeembed=true&playerId=kaltura_player&entry_id=0_oswzfw8h

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: An error occurred during message processing and no re...
entry.content:
Hi @sakshi_tekale 

Your retry is not triggered because the Exception Subprocess ends with an Escalation End Event, which marks the error as handled.
In JMS-backed delivery assurance, retries only occur when the error is unhandled and propagates back to the runtime.

To enable retries, you must either:

  • remove the Escalation End Event,

  • replace it with an Error End Event,

  • or rethrow the exception inside your subprocess.

Once the exception is allowed to reach the JMS adapter, CPI will automatically retry based on your JMS delivery assurance configuration.

entry.title: Re: Brand Field in Product master data
entry.content:
Hi Dinesh,

Are you working in a SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system configured for Retail?

As we understand, the Product Brand is part of the Retail functionality

Help on the CDS View for Product Brand

"The articles used in retail are mainly manufacturer or private labels. During article master maintenance, you can categorize articles by assigning them to a label. You can also use this categorization for reporting purposes.

This CDS view provides the data to answer the following business question:

  • What are different brands available in the system that are used to categorize retail articles?"

Applications to Maintain Article Master

The Product Master (A2X) does appear to support update to this field: help link with sample payload, you can investigate if you can update it there but it could be restriction if you are not in a Retail system: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/d2d45480188e4752a778bd173b54384a.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US
